Ma. Elvie L. is 40 years of age and is a resident of Siari, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married to Alberto L., a fisherman and they have two children.

This is her first loan. Her other source of income is fish-vending. Her future plan for her business is to raise more pigs in order to help pay for the education of her children and to hope to gain a good future.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.es:
La señora Gabriela es casada con el señor santiago Eduardo Garcia y son padres de una hermosa niña de edad escolar.
Ella labora para una clínica como jefa de enfermeras desde hace 2 años, su esposo trabaja para una clínica de primeros auxilios como radioperador, desde hace un año.
Ellos están solicitando este crédito para las instalaciones eléctricas de su vivienda ya que se quemaron y están batallando por concepto de la luz.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gabriela is married to Mr. Santiago Eduardo Garcia and both are parents of a beautiful girl of school age.

Gabriela has been working as head nurse for a clinic for two years. Since a year ago, her husband works for a first aid clinic as a radio operator.

They need a loan to install electricity in their home as it burnt out and they are in dire need of light.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install electricity in her home.

loans.name: Lerica

texts.en: Lerica M. is from the village of Ospital. She is 48 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Lerica owns and operates a "sari-sari" (general) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month In 2004, Lerica joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lerica is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 22nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en: Lucita P. is from the village of Macabayao, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, is married, and has seven adult children. Lucita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2003, Lucita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Lucita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

texts.es:
La señora Verónica es casada y madre de dos pequeñitos, su esposo el señor Félix Horacio labora en una empresa en el área de técnico en mantenimiento desde hace 6 años. Ella es propietaria de un pequeño negocio de venta de quesos y chorizo desde hace 7 años.
Motivo por el cual esta solicitando este crédito lo cual es para la compra de mas mercancía.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong S., age 31, is married and resides with four of her children in Takeo province, Cambodia. All the children are students.

Kong has a business selling chickens in the local market, earning approximately US$3 of profit per day, while her husband works collecting palm juice to refine it to palm sugar. He typically makes about US$3 as well.

Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses so they want to have a loan to expand their businesses. This will provide the family with more income and also will enable the children to take a higher class.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to sell

loans.name: Melde

texts.en:
Melde G. is from the village of Sinara Alto, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Melde owns and operates a business venture in the services sector, selling charcoal in the local community. Melde has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $112 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Melde joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melde has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. Melde is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This will be her fifth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand her services

texts.en:
Lydia O. is from the village of Brgy. 26, Gingoog City. She is 22 years old. Lydia is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Lydia operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (about $63) a month for these activities.

In September 2009, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lydia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean L. lives in the village of P-5, Brgy. San Juan Gingoog City. She is 23 years old, married and has three very young children. To make a living, she owns and operates a food stall. Jean has run this business for more than three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP from her work.

Earlier this year, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business opportunities. She is now applying for her first loan to buy ingredients to make more food to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to continue to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Mary-Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 26 years old and lives in Barangay Bantay Solana, Cagayan, where most people make a living in agriculture. She is married to Romulo, a local farmer, and they blessed with three children: Ronel, who is 9 years old, Roderick, who is 7 and Marielle, who is 2. They have a good family life and everyone is happy despite their poverty. 

For the last year, Mary Ann has made a living selling vegetables and raising chickens. She works hard and is patiently trying to expand both businesses so that her family has a better life. She uses some of the income she makes from selling vegetables to buy feed for her chickens. Mary Ann is applying for this loan to buy more of the supplies she needs to run both of her small businesses.

loans.use: To buy supplies to expand two small businesses

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen T. is married with two children. She lives with her husband (pictured) in Kompong Chnang Province. To make a living, she is engaged in the agriculture sector of raising pigs, typically earning US $3 per day. Her husband operates his mechanical plow providing services of transporting goods for local villagers in his village, earning an income of US $5 per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family and the children. Therefore, T. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to have the mechanical plow repaired. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to have teh mechanical plow repaired

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia G. lives in the village of Brgy, San Juan Gingoog City. She is 36 years old, single and has one child. To make a living, She owns and operates a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells a wide range of items to people who live in her community. Sonia has been engaged in this business for more than four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Sonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business opportunities. She is applying for her first loan from HSPFI to buy additional items to sell. She plans to use the additional income generated by this loan to expand and improve her small business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell

texts.en:
Zenaida is  45 years old and she is married to Marcelo, a local farmer in their village at Bantay Solana, Cagayan. The couple is blessed with two children: Ronel, 25 years old and his twin sister Mildred.  Milded her daughter is able to graduate from college and now teaching in a public school in their place. 

Zenaida is managing a general store business. Her store is doing well and is full of different merchandise. Though her store is small, Zenaida is hoping that someday, she will able to expand the business in order to gain higher income. Doing this encourages her to request for additional business capital from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP6, 000. According to her, she will use the loan to purchase additional items such as two sacks of rice to retail and other grocery items that are very in demand in their village.  She dreams to improve her business and to become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.name: Dylinda

texts.en: Dylinda T. makes a living growing rice in Agusan Del Sur. She is 49 years old, married, has four children and is a member of CEVI, the first microfinance organization she has ever joined. Dylinda is happy to receive financial help because she is able to make good use of it on her farm. She is applying for this loan to buy items she needs to raise her crop and expand her small business.

loans.use: To buy materials and supplies for her farm

loans.name: Lourdes

Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lourdes joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be her sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

Sonia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia used to believe that “it is better to give than to receive”, that helping other people in simple ways is showing a good attitude towards others and to God. She manages a bakeshop business located along the National Highway of Cordon, Isabela.

Lydia is happily married to Arnolfo, her business partner. The couple are gifted with two children: Arlan Jay - 12 years old, an elementary student, and Ashie Jhaira - 4 years old, already in preschool.

Lydia dreams of having a successful life. However, her business capital is not enough and that is why she is asking to borrow PHP 50,000 in financial assistance from Kiva lenders as additional capital for the progress of their bakeshop business.

Lydia also wants to have her own retailing business that she could manage, to help generate additional income for their family. According to her, they are doing all these things to give their two children a better future and also to provide employment to some of their neighbors.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Jobel

texts.en:
Jobel G., 41 years old owns a number of lights, fertilizers, and amplifiers. He has three children, 8 years the eldest who are all studying in school. People are renting his lights, amplifiers and other disco utilities which eventually gives him income to rpovide food, clothng and  other basic needs in their family.

He would like to request a loan of Php 25,000 from Community Economic Ventures. He will use the loan to buy  additional speakers, ligts and amplifiers to improve his services.

loans.use: Buy additional speakers, ligts and amplifiers

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco S. is a 74 years old man from the village of Kinangay Sur,Clarin,Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Francisco is married and has four adult children. To make a living,Francisco owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating passenger motor services in the local community.Francisco has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately  10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Francisco joined GDMPC in 2004 to access financial services and engage in business activities, which helps to improve his living situation.Francisco has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 from GDMPC. Francisco is requesting a new loan of  24,000.00 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his motor services. This will be Franciso 13th loan from GDMPC, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan C. is 71 years old and widowed. She lives with her two children. She makes a living by selling rice and raising animals for a daily income of $3. The family is also assisted by one her children who is tourist guide, earning approximately an income of US $12 per day. Also, another son is engaged in a business of providing transportation services to people in the town, earning the same amount of income to his mother. She plans to take a KIVA loan of $1200 to build a place to store rice that she will buy it from the local farmers in her village. With the remainder, she wants to expand her business by purchasing more rice. She hopes that, with the success of her business plan, she will be able to decorate her house.

loans.use: build a place to store rice

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena T., 41 years old, owns a small sari-sari (general) store. She has four children, 22 years old the eldest, and a very supportive husband who helps her manage the business. Aside from selling a variety of goods, she indulges herself in selling fish to supplement their income. She also earns enough from the fish that she sells to help a lot in meeting their needs everyday.

Lucena would like to grow her business. She has an idea how to do it so now she needs additional capital to use to increase the variety of goods in her store and, hopefully, the fish that she sells. The loan will help her improve the size of her store to earn a better and bigger income.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store

texts.en: Morm S. is married with two children. She lives with her husband in Kompong Chnang Province. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling groceries, typically earning US $3 per day. Her husband operates his motor taxi in the town and other nearby local markets, earning an income of US $2 of net profit per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family and the children. Therefore, S. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase various kinds of groceries and soft drink to expand her current business. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

Elisa T., 45 years old is a store owner who sells also rice in their own village. She has two children, 12 years old the eldest and all are in elementary grades school. She started her sari-sari store way back 1998 because she doesn't have any livelihood to get for money to buy food and clothing.

Now, he store is quite bigger than before. However, she still needs additional capital to get along with the demands of her customers. She needs atleast Php 25,000 to add her merchandise display so that she will be able to offer her customers more selctions with variety.

In 2009, Beverly joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to buy materials for the construction of her store. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She is 30 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study.  Mrs. Dalen D. is a water seller. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing a machine, to pump water for sale. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a machine to pump water.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn Y. is married with a school-aged child. She lives with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province.

Y. is engaged in the business of selling dessert in a local market, typically earning US$1.50 per day. Her husband is a soldier in the province, earning an income of US$2 per day. Both of them have to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their family and for their child.

Therefore, Y. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US$350 to purchase a calf to raise and sell. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to generate a good standard of living for her family.

texts.en:
Fernando C., 53 years old, is the father of two children and is a rice grower in Norala, Sout Cotabato. His eldest is 19 years old. He wants to send his child to college but his income is not enough to afford the tuition fees, books and other school fees.

Now, Fernando needs to borrow money to support his farm. He would like to request a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy farming necessities to improve his harvest size. Without this loan, he might have to go to loan sharks who put high interest rates on their loans.

Edith H., 60 years old is still tilling her rice field which she hopes could give her income to buy food, clothing and other basic needs. She has two children that are married already. She started having a farm since 1971 which is also the same year that she got married to her husband.

She would like to request for aloan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use her loan to grow her rice plant and in buying the farming necessities to obtain abundant harvest. Currently, she has 5 hectare farm, which she really depends on for all her needs.

Jimmy D. C. is a rice grower on a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) rice farm in Norala, South Cotabato in Mindanao. The income he makes from growing rice has evidently helped his family to buy food, clothing and other basic needs.

Jimmy would like to ask for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to help grow his rice plants well and to buy farm necessities. The loan will really help him so that he no longer needs to go for loans to loan sharks who put high interest rates on their loans.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of foods, snacks, and other delicacies in the local community. Isidra has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Isidra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isidra is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make the food she sells. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Isidra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

Leonora D., 60 years old, is a rice farmer in Norala, South Cotabatoo in Mindanao. She has six children that are married already. Currently, she only has 1 and 1/2 hectare rice foeld which she hopes would give her family enough income to buy food, clothing and oter basic needs.

Now, she would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to grow her rice plant healthy by buying the farming necessities. The loan is truly helpful for her to be able to obtain maximum harvest.

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie V. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Analie is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Analie owns & operates a specialized "sari-sari" variety store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. Analie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Analie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analie is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Analie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

texts.en:
Jomie D., 32, owns and tills a 1 and a 1/2 hectare farm. He has two children, who are studying. The rice field is his only way to support his family since this is the only job that he is familiar with.

He is doing his best to support his family's everyday needs. Now, he would like to request a loan of PHP 12,000 from Communty Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to make his rice plants grow healthy, and to buy other farming necessities.

Erlinda T., 59 years old, tills a rice farm in Norala South Cotabato in Mindanao. She has 8 children who no longer live with them. Her farm is almost 3 hectares, and she hopes it will provide her with enough income to buy food, clothing and other basic needs.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy the necessary materials for her farm. Receiving this loan will help her to develop her business and provide more income.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena N. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 62 years old. Magdalena is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Magdalena owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Magdalena has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Magdalena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Magdalena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

texts.en: Ly S., age 54, is married and resides with two of her children in Kompong Chnang province, Cambodia. All the children help their parents with the business to help the family. S. has a business selling groceries and coffee, earning approximately $2.50 of profit per day, while her husband has a business of purchasing cows from the village and reselling them for a profitable price, typically earning about US$8 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses, so they want to take out a loan to expand their businesses. She wants to take out a loan of US $1000 to buy a motor bike for her husband to improve his business.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea R., age 27, is married and resides with her two children in Kompong Chnang province, Cambodia. R. has a business selling fruit, earning approximately $2.50 of profit per day, while her husband has a business of providing transportation services to people in the town and other nearby local markets in the province, typically earning about US$5 per day. He also rents big speakers, amplifiers, and sound mixers to people in his village when they celebrate any ceremony. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses, so they want to take out a loan to expand their businesses. R. wants to take out a loan of US $900 to purchase more speakers and sound mixers to rent in order to generate more income for the family.

loans.use: To buy speakers and sound mixers.

texts.en: Bou S., 58, is married and resides with her two children in Kompong Chnang province, Cambodia. S. is involved in the agriculture sector as a rice field farmer, earning approximately $2 of profit per day, while her husband is currently employed in a private factory in the town, typically earning about US$2 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they have been employed, so they want to take out a loan to maximize the yield from their farm. S. wants to take out a loan of US $800 to buy fertilizer, and she wants to repair her house with any remaining funds from the loan.

Hun D., age 31, is married and resides with her three school-aged children in Kompong Chnang province, Cambodia. D. is employed in a local garment factory, earning approximately $2.60 of profit per day, while her husband is a construction worker, typically earning about US$2 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they have been employed, so they would like to take out a loan of US $600 to purchase animals to raise. Any money left over from the loan will be used to repair her house.

loans.name: Nhien's Group

texts.en:
Nhiên Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120001) was born in 1957. She lives in Xom Vang, Co Loa, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She has two sons, both of whom have a job. Her family has a store at home where she sells cakes, sweet (candies), Coca Cola, etc. Her husband helps her sell, too. Beside her store, she grows rice and raises fish, pigs and chickens. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,500,000 VND. She is part of a cluster group. She has taken part in SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) for five years. This time, she wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND to invest in her general store.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Thành Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120002) was born in 1969. She has one child. She wants to borrow 4,578,000 VND to buy piglets to raise.

Yến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120015) was born in 1961. She has two children. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

Hà Thị T. Đặng (id: 010102120014) was born in 1969. She has three children. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to raise chickens.

Hà Thị C. (id: 010102120004) was born in 1971. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy rice to make rice cakes to sell.

Sở Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120011) was born in 1960. She has three children. She makes tofu. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy soybeans.

Yến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120005) was born in 1970. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy feed for her fish and pigs.

Liêm Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120017) was born in 1972. She has three children. She is a tailor. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to buy cloth.

loans.use: To invest in her general store

texts.en: Nhem S., age 43, is married and resides with her two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. S. is involved in a business of selling food, earning approximately $10 of profit per day, while her husband operates his motor taxi in the city, typically earning about US$5 per day. Standard of living has been improved since they have these businesses, so they want to have a loan of US $1000 to purchase utensils, vegetable, and meat to expand her business.

Khơ Thị N.'s main job is farming. She grows rice and raises pigs. Every day, she works at many things: housework, cooking, and care of grandchildren. Her family includes her husband, three children, a daughter-in-law and two grandsons. Her husband is a hairdresser. Her son is an electrician.

Khơ Thị N. was born in 1959. She lives in Xom Mit, Uy No, Dong Anh. Her family has a monthly income of about 5.500.000 dong. She has taken part in SEDA for five years and repaid on time. This time, she wants to borrow 5.450.000 dong to breed pigs and poultry. ID: 010102090020

To borrow with her, is Mrs Thuc. Thức Thị N. is a worker. She was born in 1968. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 dong to buy piglets and feed for them. ID: 010102090021

Marilyn Navarro, 49 years old rice grower in Noral South Cotabato in Mindanao. She has three children, 28 years old the eldest who are now working. Currently, she tills a 1 and 1/2 hectare farm which she hopes could give her family enough income to help buy food. c;lothing, and other basic needs.

She is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farming necessities in order to have an abundant harvest.

She said she joined in CEVI credit program since 2008. She likes the policies that is why she stayed in CEVI.

Đáp Thị Lê was born in 1966. ( id: 010102130009). She lives in Xom Thuong, Co Loa, Dong Anh. She has four children. The oldest son is a driver. Other children are students. She sells fruits in the market. She and her husband go to the market each other. Her husband helps her as: ride fruits, to do housework, raise pigs, ete. But their main job is farming. They have a monthly income of about 5.000.000 VND. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to small business.
 About the other borrower in her group:
 Thật Thị Nguyễn was born in 1957. ( id: 010102130008). She has two children. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to breed the pigs and poultry. 
 Bé Thị Nguyễn was born in 1958. ( id: 010102130015).  She grows vegetables. She has a Mechanical workshop. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND to invest in her Mechanical workshop.

Loida F. is a rice grower of a farm that is  1 and 1/2 hectare in size. She has working so hard to be able to improve their harvest and earn an income to buy food, clothes and other basic needs. In addition to rice, she also raises chickens and cow. The loan which she keeps on availing from Community Economic Ventures Inc. has helped sustained her business.

She would like to ask a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farming necessities. receiving this loan will help him to not pursue her loan form other loansharks who puts higher interest rate in their loans.

Emmie A. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 29 years old. Emmie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Emmie owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dried fish in the local community. Emmie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years with an approximate average monthly earnings of 3,000 PHP from these activities.

In 2007, Emmie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emmie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Emmie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in a sari-sari store and raising pigs, in addition to her existing business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Emmie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees so that they can finish their studies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Lucia G., 52 years old is a rice farmer in Veruela Agusan Del Sur. She has nine children, 15 years old the eldest that are studying. In most cases, she worried a lot how would she budget their limited income and pay everything like the school tution, clothes and their other needs. The farm is really helpful since they no longer buy rice for their food consumption. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 ffrom Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farming necessities. receiving this loan is helpful because she doesn't have money to support her business now.

loans.name: Felista

texts.en:
Felista is a member of the Semtema borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 32 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 12, 9, 5, 1 years old.

Felista has owned a shop business for 2 years, she works 13 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 220,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Felista`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tanzanian shillings in order to buy more commodities like rice, cooking oil, wheat to her business.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Falista hopes to save more money and expand  her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for sale

texts.en: Inna is married and live in a private house with their son. Inna sells tights and socks at the central market in Melitopol city and has been in this business for 12 years. Inna is a very entrepreneurial and open person. She knows her business well enough and what kind of inventories to purchase. Moreover, the good location of her kiosk also helps the business. Inna would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment of fall inventories. She hopes to make additional income and finish renovations at her house.

loans.name: Mwanne

texts.en:
Mwanne is a member of the Mbuma borrower group in Kihesa, Irnga, she is 57 year old woman, she is married and a  mother of 1 child, her child is 40 years old.

Mwanne has owned a Grocery business for 25 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Mwanne`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more beer and soda.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwanne hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  Drinks like beer and soda

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn T. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 39 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling native coconut wine known as "tuba" produced by her husband in the local community. Jocelyn is just starting this business. In 2006, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which she will use to purchase construction materials to repair her house. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to have comfortable shelter for her family to live in. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for house repair.

loans.name: Kathelini

texts.en:
Kathelini is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 18, 16, 14, 9 years old.

Kathelini has owned a business for 8 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Katelini`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more beans and soap  for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Kathelini hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap, Beans for sale

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is a vegetable vendor. She is married and she and her husband were gifted with five children. With the help of her business, she has successfully sent her children to school and two of them graduated with a college degree. Merlita continuously works hard in her business for the education of her children.  
 
Merlita wanted to borrow a loan amount of PHP17,000 for the maintenance of her vegetable farm. She plans to buy farm inputs like fertilizers and pesticides to have good harvests and to earn more income.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy items such as fertilizers and pesticides.

texts.en: Lydia P. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 54 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Lydia runs a general store. She sells a variety of different products in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities. In 2007, Lydia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Lydia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Lolita is a hog raiser in their village. She is married and they were gifted with one child. Her husband is working as a tricycle (local three-wheeled motorcycle) operator and his income is being used to support their daily needs and also for her hog-raising business.

With her business, she can assist her husband in providing the needs of their family. And to further improve her business, she is now asking to borrow PHP 17,000 that she can use for the maintenance of her hog-raising business.

Yus S. is 32 years old and resides in the Phnom Penh with her husband and three of her children. Since 2008, she has been selling food, meat, beers and beverage to earn a living and is able to make about US$8every day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. He typically makes US$1 a day. Two of the children are in school and one is too young to attdent. Yus is asking for a loan of US$1200 to expand her business by purchasing more chairs and tables.

Lanie has been managing a general store for four years. She is married and they have three children. According to Lanie, having a family is not easy, especially providing them with the best education. They are living in Dalig Viejo, Burgos, Isabela. Her monthly profit from her business is Php 4,000 and it is already a big help to meet the needs of their family.

Lanie would like to request a loan amounting to PHP 27,000 that she can use as additional capital for her general store. This amount will help her to make her business grow as well as improving their living conditions.

Mrs. Chanra C. is a Khmer cake maker. She is 24 years old and the mother of two children who are just 1 and 3 years old. Her husband, Mr. Soth Kork, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In his plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field is infertile, which has a bad effect on his crops. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Chanra C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer for the field to make the soil more productive.

Mrs. Chanra C. is the village bank president. This village bank loan is for ten people living in Serei Duoch village in Takeo province. The members will use the loan for different purposes.

Nine members in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans and one member has a monthly payment loan. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en:
Mhammad is a 26 year old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their child. Mhammad has been working in the sanitary since 2006. Mhammad requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to pay his working car debt. This is the first time that Mhammad has requested a loan. 
Mhammad is special because he has competitive prices. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Mhammad decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work and improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on expanding his work by opening a sanitary shop.

loans.use: To pay his working car debt.

texts.en: Pen C., 27, is a widow with a young child and resides in the Phnom Penh. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3. Pen is asking for a loan of US$500 to expand her grocery stand.

loans.name: Neyaz

texts.en:
Neyaz has owned a clothing shop for four years. Neyaz is a 49 year old woman who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband and their two children. When she first started her business, she didn’t have any startup capitA.. Neyaz decided on this business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. Neyaz knows how to treat her clients, who are her friends and neighbors.

Neyaz requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. She has been a microcredit client for eight years now and has always paid on time. Her previous loans helped her diversify her merchandise. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

texts.en:
Eunice is engaged in vegetable vending business.  Aside from this, she is also raising hogs in their backyard. She is 28byears old, married and gifted with two children. She sells her own harvested vegetables and her income from this is being used to provide the needs of their family.  

At present, Eunice wanted to borrow the amount of Php27, 000 for the maintenance and expansion of their vegetable farm to be able to have a good harvest. She is hoping that her request will be approved to have additional capital so she can also improve her piggery and have an increase in income.

texts.fr:
A. Florence est née vers les années 1971 à Abomey, Capitale historique du Bénin. Florence est
mariée DOSSOU Julien, mécanicien moto de formation qui s’est reconverti dans la revente de véhicules d’occasion. Florence est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés dont l’aîné en classe de cinquième.La famille vit à Xwlacodji un bidonville de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Depuis 6 ans, Florence a pour activité la vente de charbon de bois; une activité que Florence exerce dans le son quartier à Xwlacodji. Dans le but d’agrandir son stock de charbon et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Florence contracta son premier prêt à ALIDé en 2007. Cette expérience de prêt a été fructueuse à Florence et récemment, elle a débuté aussi la vente de boisson liqueur produit localement.
Florence a déjà eu quatre crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de ses activités. Pour continuer à développer ses activités, Florence demande un cinquième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Florence A. was born around 1971 in Abomey, the historic capital of Benin. Florence is married to Julien Dossou, an auto mechanic by training who has switched to selling second-hand vehicles. Florence is the mother of three children, all in school, of whom the eldest is in seventh grade. The family lives in Xwlacodji, a shantytown in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. For 6 years, Florence has had a business selling charcoal; she runs this activity in her area in Xwlacodji. With the aim of enlarging her stock of charcoal and better satisfying her clientele, Florence took out her first loan through ALIDE (one of Kiva's field partners) in 2007. This loan experience was fruitful for Florence, and she recently began selling locally-produced alcoholic beverages. Florence has already obtained four loans through ALIDE, all of which she repaid without problems, and with which she was able to raise the level of her business. To continue developing her business activities, Florence is seeking a fifth loan to strengthen her working capital.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Night

texts.en: Night B. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at the resturant  and is requesting a loan to purchase more meat and rice to cook and sell.  Night is 28 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for rent BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more meat, rice and cook to sell

texts.en: Dul S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Phnom Penh. Since 2006, she has been selling food and grocery items to earn a living, and is able to make about US$3 of profit every day, while her husband makes US$2 working as a teacher. This couple has one young child. Dul S. is asking for a loan of US$400 to fix her leaking roof.

Sim S., 36, is a garment factory worker and resides in the Phnom Penh with her husband and two of her children. She typically makes US$3 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a motor-taxi driver who makes US$3 per day as well. Due to the difficult of leaking roof, Mrs. Sim is asking a loan of US$1200 to fix it.

Segundina is engaged in calamansi (citrus fruit) business.  She plants and sell calamansi in wholesale price.  She has been nine years in the business and she is really enjoying working with the support of her family especially her husband. 

"The power of God within you is greater than the pressures around you”. This quote guides her to live a good life and have patience in order to make her business grow. At present, she wanted to borrow the amount of PHP32, 000.00 to have an additional capital for the maintenance of her business. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her request.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora is a member of the Tanganyika borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 18, 13, 9,  and 5 years old.

Debora has owns a shop business selling rice,beans, salts oil etc for 12 years, she works 12  hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 220,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Debora`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Debora hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities for business

texts.en:
Teresita is 40 years old.  She is engaged in vegetable vending business.  Every day she wake up early in the morning to go to the market and buy vegetables and snacks that she will eventually sell in their village in retail price.  Waking up early in the morning is not easy to do, but Teresita will do her best in order to support the education of her children.  She believes that education is the only wealth she can give to her children.

Teresita is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP12,000.  This amount will be used for the sustainability of her business for the benefit of her family.

loans.name: Xaveur

texts.en:
Xaveur N. is 31 years old and is married with one child. He has been running his shop for three years working ten hours a day.

Xaveur is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through buying more products. With that expansion, Xaveur hopes to earn more profit than before. Then, through that profit, he will be able to buy his own house and save for his family.

Through accessing this loan, Xaveur expects to have a positive change in his life and a better future for his family.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for his shop

texts.en:
Jocelina has been in the direct selling business for 15 years.  At present, she is working as a dealer of Natasha, Boardwalk, MSE, and Avon cosmetics and apparel products. She manages the business since when she is still single. Jocelina is now married and blessed with two children and they are both in high school level.  Her business serves as her source of income while her husband is selling different detergent soaps in different villages.  The couple is working hard to meet the needs of their family and also to support the education of their children.  

Jocelina uses her income for the tuition fees of their children and for the improvement of their living condition.  She wanted to avail a loan of PHP32,000 that she can use as additional capital for her business.  This amount will help her to buy more products and have a business expansion.

loans.name: Anzetse

texts.en:
Anzetse is 56 years old,married and is blessed with four children.

His business is located in west market and he serves residents who live within west market.

Anzetse was introduced to KADET by another client.With the loan he is taking from KADET,he intends to buy more stock for his business which includes ingredients for juice preparation also and food stuff.In future he will like to diversify his products to include cereal and also educate his children.

”About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke “

loans.use: To add more stock which includes ingredients for drinks(juice )preparation.

loans.name: Joséphine

texts.fr: A. KAÏ Joséphine est âgée de trente six ans et est née à Ouidah  dans le Département de l’Atlantique au Sud du BENIN. Joséphine est mariée. Joséphine est mère de 4 enfants: 3 sont encore à leur charge son mari et elle; deux scolarisés respectivement en classe de sixième et de CE1; le troisième est encore au biberon. Joséphine est une revendeuse de produits de mer au port de pêche de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Joséphine a une grande clientèle constituée dans sa majorité des dames qui sont dans la restauration. le premier prêt de Joséphine lui a permis de répondre un tout petit peu aux besoins de sa clientèle. Avec son deuxième prêt, Joséphine a diversifié son activité à la vente de tissus. Joséphine sollicite son troisième prêt pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Joséphine A. Kaï is 36 years old and was born in Ouidah in the Atlantique au Sud department of Benin. Joséphine is married. Joséphine is the mother of 4 children: 3 are still in her and her husband's care; two are in school, in sixth and second grade; the third is still a baby. Joséphine is a retailer of seafood products at the fishing port in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Joséphine has a large clientele composed mainly of women who are involved in meal preparation and catering businesses. The first loan Joséphine obtained allowed her to respond a little bit to the needs of her clientele. With her second loan, Joséphine diversified her business by selling fabric. Joséphine is seeking her third loan to strengthen her working capital.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seafood products and bolts of fabric

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila T. is from the village of Tubod. She is 51 years old. Leonila is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Leonila owns & operates a airbrush painting business in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing painting services to local community members. Leonila has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonila has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 45000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 13th loan taken out by Leonila from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

texts.en:
Marina is engaged in dress making business for 13 years.  She started her business when she got married as her way of helping her husband in providing the needs of her family and also for them to have an alternative source of income aside from farming.  She is 58 years old and still striving to work hard for the sake of her family.  She is glad that through God's help, her business is still stable.  

Marina would like to improve her business.  This is the reason why she wanted to borrow a loan of PHP15,000 for the maintenance of her business. She is praying that her request will be approved to be able to increase her profit and reach her goals in life.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Be Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan which consists of eleven people and they all live in Tboung Damrei village in province. Mrs. Sokha B. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a pig breeder. Since her pigs are bigger and bigger, they need many foods. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food for her breeding pigs business. Her husband, Mr. Heng Sovath, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. Mrs. Sokha B. is 44 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is construction worker while the others are attending the local school. 
   
Eight members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy pig food for her breeding pigs business.

texts.en: Kim Sokum is 55 years old and resides with her husband in Phnom Penh. She is a professional tailor who is able to make US$ 1.50 in profit every day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and makes US$ 2 per day. Kim would like to ask for a loan of US$  200 to fix her leaking roof.

loans.name: Teodula

texts.en:
Teodula D. is from the village of Punta. She is 56 years old. Teodula is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Teodula owns and operates a "carenderia" (restaurant) in the food sector. The main source of income for the business comes from serving local foods to customers in the local community. Teodula has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for this activity.

In 2005, Teodula joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodula has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Teodula is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Teodula from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en:
Josie is engaged in vegetable planting and selling business.  She sells her own crops in the public market in their community.  She is 45 years old and still very diligent in making her business productive.  Her business has been her partner in providing the needs of their family and also in supporting the educational needs of her children.

At present, she is seeking for financial assistance from KIVA lenders to avail a loan of PHP15,000.00.  She believes that with their support, she could be able to maintain the needs of her vegetable farm like fertilizers and pesticides for the protection of the quality of their vegetables.

loans.name: Elyse

texts.en:
Elyse B. is 23 years old, single and he is in a business of cooking breads for 2 years working 11 hours a day.

Elyse after realizing that his investment is still low and that the profit he gets is too low to go ahead in his business, he is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for the purpose of expanding his business then with that expansion, he will get more profit than before.

With that profit, he will be able to build his own house and save for his future.

loans.use: Purchasing more products for making Breads

loans.name: Sombua

texts.en: Sombua B. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in the resturant and is requesting a loan to purchase more tables and chairs in her resturant.  Sombua is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a teacher . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her resturant  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. texts.en:
Sara is a member of the Tanganyika borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 12, 8, 2 years old.

Sara has owned a Tailoring business for 2 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Sara`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials for sale.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan,Sara hopes to save money, pay school fees  and expand her business.

Teresita is engaged in the hog raising business as her source of income.  She us 54byears old and she is already a widow and she was left with their four children. In order to cope with their family needs, Teresita also works in the field for extra income.  She can earn a labor fee of PHP100.00 a day and sometimes she even washed clothes of her neighbors and earn an income of PHP150.00. 

Being a single parent is hard especially in providing the needs of her children.  Teresita wanted to borrow a loan amount of PHP12,000 from the KIVA fellows for the maintenance of her hog raising business and to purchase feeds supply.  She hopes that her request will be approved to be able to attain her goals in life.

loans.name: Faustin

texts.en:
Faustin M. is 32 years old, is single, and he takes care of his four brothers.

Faustin has operated a beauty salon since 2007 where he employs four people working eleven hours a day. His desire is to request his first loan from Vision Finance Company which will permit him to expand his salon by buying more equipment and employing more than four people.

By receiving this loan, Faustin hopes to see his salon growing and earning more profit than before. It is with that profit that he will be able to take care of his brothers and send them to school.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for his salon

texts.en:
Lan Thị B. T. was born in 1977. ( id: 010103060029). She lives in Ly Nhan, Duc Tu, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She has two children. Her husband is a carpenter. They have a workshop at home. Every day, Mrs Lan goes to work far her house. She parches wood to make mayches. Beside, she raises pigs. She has a monthly income of about 4.000.000 VND. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND to buy food for pigs.
 About the other borrower in her group:
 Hồng Thị Nguyễn was born in 1957. ( id: 010103060025). She has three children. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND to breed the pigs.

Veronica is 55 years old and she is engaged in the 'sari-sari' business (running a community-based store). She is married and her husband is working as a farmer. They have seven children and having a big family is very challenging especially in providing their needs and in sending them to school.

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 22,000 from KIVA lenders. She believes that this amount will really help her in making her store more profitable and also to achieve her dreams for her family.

loans.name: Poni

 G. is 20 years old and is Married with a husband that is a security guard. She has 1 child and her child does not go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

To make a living, Letecia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, running a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling bananas in the local community. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Mrs. Pol Bun Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 13 people living in the village of Tboung Damrei in the province of Takeo. Each member will use their loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Pol B. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a food seller. Her husband, Mr. P. Prunh, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivates rice. He is currently encountering a problem because his field has infertile soil. For this reason, Mrs. Pol B. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer with which to support the field in order to make crop more productive. She is 61 years old and the mother of a grown child who is a construction worker.

Six members in this group loans have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. She used to own a dress-making business, however, she temporarily closed it and decided to venture into raising hogs.

Visitacion dreams of continuing her dressmaking business because it was her major source of income before. She wanted to have additional capital, and that's why she is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 from KIVA lenders for the maintenance of her hog-raising business and to earn more income. She is hoping that God will make a way to be able to make her business successful someday and to reach all her goals in life.

She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND to buy food for pigs.

For this plantation, Mrs. Koem Rong B. is applying a loan to buy fertilizer and she would use the rest of the money to buy two piglets to raise. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. She is 36 years old and the mother of four children who are enrolled in the local school.
