loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en: Mrs. Nerissa G. is 27 years old and lives in Tamil, Jose Dalman. She is married to Marlo G., who works for National Highways, and they have two children. Nerissa is a member of the special program of Kiva partner, Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). She is in good standing as a member of PMPC in her center at Yellow Bells. Because of her performance in the center, she is able to take a second-cycle loan of 8,000 PHP. She intends to use this loan as additional capital for her business. She patiently retails gasoline along the highway with her little stall. She plans to use the additional income generated from the business to pay her loan, to sustain the daily needs of her family, and to prepare for her children's education. She gives her warmest thanks to PMPC for the benefits of the program and its services, especially for insuring her whole family.

loans.use: As additional capital for her gasoline vending business

location.town: Tamil, Jose Dalman Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty C. is from the village of Camp Phillips Bukidnon. She is 48 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a business selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal home products to local community members. Betty has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Betty joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Betty is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

texts.en: Ahmad is a 43-year-old married man and father of 4 children. He has owned a car repair shop since 2004 and has 15 years of experience in this field. Today, Ahmad is requesting to borrow $1,000 to renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

Raymonde is a 47-year-old married woman and mother of 2 children. She has owned a clothes shop called "Maguy" since 2000 to earn income to cooperate her husband in the household. Today, Raymonde is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy more clothes for her shop, and to satisfy the needs of her customers.

Amos H. is 39 years old and a widow. She has four children who all go to school. Amos has a retail business in a shop made of iron sheets, and she is requesting a loan to build a concrete shop. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Pol

texts.en: Pol S. is a 60-year-old widow who makes her livelihood in the countryside. She has three children, two of whom are married and live separately. S. runs a service sewing clothes at home. She also helps her single son, Sophon, 41, farm rice and seasonal vegetables on a plot of land inherited from her parents. Sophon and S. have sustained their small family by their farming. Recently, they needed cows to plow their field in order to avoid paying to hire cows. So they took a loan of $175 USD to buy a pair of cows for their farm. (Sophon was not available for the photograph so S. had her picture taken alone.)

loans.use: To buy a pair of cows to plow their farm

loans.name: Diane

texts.fr: S. Diane est née vers les années 1968 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Diane est mariée à Ahouandjinou Grégoire; elle est mère d’une fille âgée de 14 ans. Diane réside au quartier Enagnon une banlieue de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Diane mène comme activité principale la vente des produits vivriers( maïs, haricot, mil, soja, sorgho, riz...). C'est sur commande et a crédit que distribue ses produits à sa clientèle. Mais comme activité secondaire, vend aussi les fruits de ronier de façon ambulante. Diane a déjà eu quatre crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Diane demande un cinquième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs, de riz, de haricot et les fruits de ronier.

texts.en:
Phúc Thị Đào was born in 1968. She lives in Xom Mit, Co Loa, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She has three children. Her husband is a policeman in the commune. She has a store. She sells items like cigarettes, beer, sweets, Coca-Cola, etc. Besides the store, she also grows rice and raises chickens and pigs. 

She has taken part in SEDA for four years. She is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by SEDA. Everyone in her group repays loans on time. This time, she wants to borrow 5.886.000 VND to breed the pigs and the poultry. 

About the other borrowers in her group:

Xuân Thị Nguyễn was born in 1978. She has three children. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND for a small business.

Phương Thị Trương was born in 1983. She is a tailor. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy sewing machines.

Hà T. Nguyễn was born in 1978. She has two children. She sells fruit in the market. She wants to borrow 3.706.000 VND to buy more kinds of fruit to sell.

Duyên Thị Hoàng was born in 1982. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to breed pigs and poultry. 

Lan Thị Nguyễn was born in 1979. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to buy goods to sell.

Hussein is an 18-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2008, he decided to began a new career, working as a builder to earn income. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to purchase a specific machine that will facilitate and develop his work.

Sabah is a 50-year-old widow woman with 5 children. She has been working as a farmer since 1998. And thanks to her business income, she has been able to raise her children and meet their needs. Today, Sabah is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy new tools to develop her work.

loans.name: Elizerbeth

texts.en:
Elizerbeth P. is currently in the business of breaking and selling stones and is requesting a loan to purchase more tools to break stones for sale. Elizerbeth is 38 years old and is married to a husband who is a watchman. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more tools to break stones for sale

texts.en: Jassem is a 38-year-old married man and father of 3 children. He has been working as a constructor since 2001 to earn income and provide better life conditions to his family.  Today, Jassem is applying for a loan of $1,000 to renovate his business tools.

Mehrez is a 40-year-old married man and father of 3 children. He has been working as a farmer since 2000 and has 15 years of experience in this field. Today, Merhrez is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase merchandise for his work.

loans.name: Maria Chuchi

texts.en:
Maria Chuchi T. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 36 years old. Maria Chuchi is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Chuchi owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Maria Chuchi has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Maria Chuchi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Chuchi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Maria Chuchi is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Maria Chuchi from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

texts.en: Abdel Jalil is a 57-year-old married man with 3 children. He works hard in collaboration with his wife to earn income to satisfy the needs of the household. He has been working in the construction sector since 1995. Today, Abdel Jalil is requesting to borrow US$ 600 to buy a new specialized machine for his business.

loans.name: Kuor

texts.en:
Kuor D. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Kuor is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to keep sending her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 28-year-old single man. He has owned a barber shop since 2007 as his own business where he services the neighboring villages. Today, Ali is applying for a loan of $1,200 to add new decor to his shop in order to attract new clients and increase his income.

loans.use: add new decor to his shop

texts.en:
Denys M. is 33 years old, married with 3 children between 12 and 4.

Denys has been shopping for one year working from 6h00M o clock up to 11h00 P.M   by employing 2 people. Denys after realizing that his investment is too low to get enough profit   to satisfy his family, he needs his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a  for expanding his shop through purchasing more goods. After getting this loan, Denys hopes to get more profit than before and with that profit, he hopes to build a better future for his family and help many people by creating jobs for them.

Maya is a married woman living with her husband in her family house. She has been working as a hairdresser on her own since 2001 and has 12 years of experience in this field. Today, Maya is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase additionA. beauty products to satisfy the demand of her clientele.

Abdel Wahab is a 39-year-old married man and father of 1 child. He has owned a wheel shop since 1999 in his town. Today, Abdel Wahab is requesting to borrow $ 1,000 to buy new tools to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

Hussein is a 42-year-old married man and father of 3 children. He is the only provider in his family; that's why he works hard to earn enough income to satisfy their needs. He has been working as a blacksmith since 2000. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase iron for his business.

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina A. is from the village of Cawa-Cawa. She is 52 years old. Monina is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns & operates an agricultural business, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Monina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years, with an approximate monthly income of 6,000 PHP for these activities. In 2006, Monina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Monina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and carpentry tools for her husband. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Monina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and carpentry tools

texts.en: Fadia is a 38-year-old divorced woman raising her only child. She has owned a clothes shop since 2006 to earn income to satisfy her child needs. Today, Fadia is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more merchandise so she can increase her sales and therefore her income.

N. Sylivia is a married woman with five children. The eldest is 22 and at University. For the last five years, she has had a water and juice packing business and she is able to make 60,000/=  profit weekly. Although her business is doing well, she is adversely affected during the rainy season as then the consumption and sales are very low. She endeavors to sell more with favorable prices. Sylivia is grateful that she is able to pay school fees out of her profits as well as expand her business by buying more raw materials. She is seeking a loan in order to buy more polythene bags for packing her solids.

loans.name: Dori

texts.en:
Dori is a 23-year-old young man living with his parents. At the beginning of this year, he decided to open his own clothes shop called "Pause" as his own business and new career.

Today, Dori is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase more clothes in order to augment his sales and develop his work.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for his shop

texts.fr: B. Cécile est née vers 1969 à Maxi dans le Département du zou. Cécile est mariée à BONOU LOKO Albert, un forestier, agent permanent de l'État. Ce couple a à charge cinq enfants tous scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Yagbé, une banlieue de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Cécile mène comme activité la vente des produits vivriers (Maïs, haricot mil, tubercule d’igname...)et des sacs de charbon de bois en gros. grâce au revenu de ses activités, Cécile vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Cécile a déjà eu trois crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Cécile demande un quatrième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Cécile B. was born around 1969 in Maxi in the Zou prefecture (in Benin). Cécile is married to Albert Bonou Loko, a forest range, a government agent. This couple has five children in the care, all of whom are in school. The family lives in the Yagbé district, a suburb of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Cécile runs a business selling food products (maize, beans, millets, yams...) and bags of charcoal in bulk. Thanks to the income from her activities, Cécile is able to help her husband in providing for the family. Cécile has already obtained three credits through ALIDE (one of Kiva's field partners), all of which she repaid without problems, and with which she was able to raise the level of her business. To continue developing her business, Cécile is seeking a fourth loan to strengthen her working capital.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Houda is a 53-year-old widow woman and mother of 3 children. After the pass of her husband, she decided to help her children in the household by working as a baker producing special Lebanese bread in her town. Today, Houda is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase tools to satisfy the needs of her clients after being known by the neighboring villages.

Georgette is a 56-year-old married woman with 1 child. She has been working as a home-base tailor since 1990. Over the years, thanks to her business income, she has been able to meet her family needs. Today, Georgette is requesting to borrow $800 to purchase a new sewing machine instead of the old one to satisfy the demand of her clienteles.

loans.name: Ruslan

texts.en:
Ruslan is married with one child. He lives and works in his home town of Kamenka. Ruslan runs a small car shop selling spare vehicle parts. His shop is conveniently located right downtown Kamenka which makes it a frequently-visited place by numerous car owners. Ruslan business is very prospective. He started out small over 10 years ago. However, today Ruslan already has about 150,000 Grivnyas in inventory. His net profit amounts to 5,000-6,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Ruslan is requesting a 17,000 Grivnya loan to buy a batch of winter tires for upcoming winter season. He wanted to invest lending funds into purchase of high quality and durable tires that he knows will sell really well this fall and winter. Additional financial assistance will give Ruslan a chance to choose from a variety of suppliers and purchase the best offered merchandise. One of other business projects Ruslan is thinking about is a grocery store. His wife and he are planning to open one in the future.

loans.use: to purchase winter tires for retail sale

loans.name: Agbantedji

texts.fr: H. Agbantedji née à Cotonou, Capital économique du Bénin et âgée de 35 ans. Agbantedji est mariée à HOUINOU Alexandre qui est matelassier. Agbantedji est mère de 4 enfants tous scolarisés. La famille réside au quartier Enagnon un bidonville de la ville de Cotonou depuis plus de 11 ans. C'est les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) que Agbantedji vend dans sa boutique à la maison et ceci depuis plus de 9 ans. Grâce au revenu de ses activités,  Agbantedji vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille.  Agbantedji a déjà eu de crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité,  Agbantedji demande un nouveau crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de pâtes alimentaires, de tomates en boîte concentrées, de savons, des œufs, des condiments de sauces...

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise K. is 29 years old, is married with one child two years old, and she takes care of one dependent.

Marie Louise has operated a beauty salon for one year and, in that salon, she employs four employees, working from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. After realizing that her saloon was too small to even welcome five clients at once, Marie Louise is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand its size and to purchase more equipment. This will enable her to welcome more clients at the same time and thereby she hopes to earn more profit than before.

Through the use of this new loan, Marie Louise has a hope for the future.

loans.use: To expand the size of her salon and purchase more equipment

loans.name: Jennifer's Group

texts.en:
Jennifer is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 39 years old and married with six children, the eldest being eighteen years old and in Secondary Six. She also takes care of other orphans.

Jennifer is a business woman involved in the sale of agricultural products. She also raises animals and poultry. Her main challenge is her lack of sufficient feed for her poultry, which results in their poor growth.

Jennifer is requesting a loan to help buy more feed for her poultry. With a loan she will be able to raise quality chickens and agricultural products, resulting in increased sales. Jennifer dreams of sending all of her children through school so that they can become self-reliant.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her poultry

texts.en:
Tatyana is a married mother of two girls. Her family is an average Ukrainian family that works hard to ensure a safe and stable future for their kids.

Tatyana runs a small business selling women’s clothing in the marketplace of her home town, Znamenka. She has been in this business for three years. Currently, she has about 10,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her net profit is about 2,000-3,000 Grivnyas a month.

Tatyana usually builds up her stock two to three times a month. She is requesting a loan of 5,534 Grivnyas to stock her kiosk with additional seasonal merchandise. Tatyana always buys marketable inventory that sells fast and well. One of her short-term plans is to open a small covered store instead of an open kiosk. Tatyana has been very prompt with her payments. She has repaid all her previous loans without any delinquencies.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma D. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 47 years old, married and has four adult children. Wilma makes food, especially snacks known as "biko" made of rice and coconut milk, for sale to the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to their financial services (she successfully repaid her previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC). Wilma is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used as additional working capital and to make an installment payment on her motorcycle.

This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Wilma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional working capital and a payment on her motorcycle

texts.en:
Vitalyi is married with a 2-year-old daughter, Mariya. His family lives in Belaya Tserkov where Vitalyi sells spare parts for farming equipment in one of the local markets. He has been working hard to make his business efficient for the last 6 years.

Presently, Vitalyi has about 96,000 Grivnyas invested in his trade. His net profit amounts to 4,400 Grivnyas a month.

Vitalyi is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional spare parts for farming machines and start selling them wholesale. This loan will not only keep Vitalyi’s business running, but will also help him keep his hired employee who has been working for him since Vitalyi first launched his enterprise.

Vitalyi loves working in this sphere of business as there are very few seasonal fluctuations and his customers come for spare parts for their machines in winter just as much as in summer.

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
N. Juliet is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 34 years old and married with 2 children, with the eldest being 8 years old. She has a retail shop that she has been running for 1 year. She is also a tailor.

From her shop, Juliet makes 150,000/= as profits. She is also looking forward to expanding her tailoring business by opening up a workshop and employing people to help out. She has a dream of seeing all her children educated to the highest level. She needs a loan to help boost her business by buying more products for the shop.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.

texts.en:
Ruslana is divorced. She raises two sons herself. Her husband doesn’t want to be involved and doesn’t help Ruslana financially.

Challenging circumstances forced her to find ways to feed her family. This is how Ruslana ended up as a market vendor and a small entrepreneur four years ago. Currently, she sells footwear in the local marketplace of her home town of Mukachevo. She has about 50,000 Grivnyas invested in her business.

Ruslana is known for her integrity and consistency in dealings with clients. She works hard to keep her venture afloat. This time Ruslana is seeking a loan of 11,000 Grivnyas to continue growing her business and working capital.

loans.name: Jane Muthoni

texts.en:
Jane Muthoni is 52 years married to Macharia. They are blessed with three children.

Her business is located in Eldoret Town.She was introduced to KADET by a friend who had information about the organization.

With the loan Jane is taking from KADET she intends to increase her stock including bananas and cereals.In future she intends to grow her business and also build a house.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase stock of bananas and cereals.

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en: M. Sarah is a 38 year old, friendly and hard working lady. She is a business woman with a charcoal selling business in Kikooza that she has owned for 15 years. She is a caring person who minds about her customers’ needs and wants and this has kept her in business with so many loyal customers. She is able to make some profits that help her look after her family including paying their school fees. Sarah is a widow with 4 children with the eldest being 23 years and in Secondary school. She needs a loan to help buy more bags of charcoal from the villages so as to increase her sock hence more sales.

loans.use: Buying more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Sabine Madeleine

texts.fr: H. Q. Sabine Madeleine est née le 22/07/1967 à Allada une ville du Département de l’Atlantique. Sabine Madeleine est mariée à AGOSSOU Léon, hôtelier et employé dans l’un des hôtels de la place. Sabine Madeleine est mère de 3 enfants tous scolarisés. La famille réside depuis 11 ans dans le quartier Yagbé une banlieue de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Sabine Madeleine vend depuis 17 ans dans sa boutique: des tissus, des chaussures, des sacs et des objets d’art au Centre de Promotion de l’Artisanat de Cotonou. Sabine Madeleine a déjà eu de crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Sabine Madeleine demande un nouveau crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement afin de répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle.

loans.use: Achat de cinq pièces de tissus, de six douzaines de sacs et des objets d’art.

loans.name: Mugoma Kweterana Rossete Byabagambi Group

texts.en:
Rossete B., second from left in this picture, is the president of her group loan. She is 46 years old, widowed with two children, and responsible for five dependents.

Rossete sells fresh foods such as cassava, sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, and bananas. She has worked in her business for over four years.

She plans to use the loan to purchase the kinds of fresh foods she already sells as well as to add more stock, hoping to gain more profits. She is a hardworking and encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase fresh foods such as cassava, sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, and bananas, as well as to add more saleable stock

loans.name: Kurbonoy

texts.en:
For the past 11 years, Kurbonoy has sold women’s national dresses. She is the married mother of five children. She is determined to provide a better living for her entire family. Kurbonoy is hardworking and kind, giving her the ideal blend of entrepreneurial determination and strong customer service. Skilled in trade and abounding in character, Kurbonoy has a strong business base.

Currently, she is seeking a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new vending facility so as to expand her business. With the increased income, Kurbonoy plans to continue growing her business and to improve the financial situation of her family.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase a new vending facility so as to expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bukorakole Nyangoma Beatrice Group

texts.en: N. Beatrice is been selected by her loan group as Cashier. She is twenty-four years old, married with three children. She operates a bar business of which she has been doing for over four years. She is requesting for the loan to boost her business by purchasing crates of beer, sodas, water, etc to meet her customers’ demand. She is so much willing to improve upon her business for big profit return. She is an active business woman whose dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To boost her business by purchasing crates of beer, sodas, water, etc to meet her customers’ demand.

loans.name: Rustamkhon

texts.en: Rustamkhon is married and has two children. He is honest, hard-working, very creative and full of new ideas. When he was working in the sphere of furniture production and assembly, he was always dreaming about starting his own business in that industry. However, he didn’t have sufficient capital and he realized he had to provide for his family and cover household expenses. That is why he opened a grocery store. Rustamkhon is requesting a loan to increase the range of his selling goods. This loan will give him a chance to buy a larger assortment of goods such as sugar, flour, vegetable oil, cereals, and many others. He believes the loan will boost his economic activity and help him generate more profits. It will not only help him grow his business but also give his family a better quality of life. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. loans.use: To increase the range of goods he sells

loans.name: Bimalohat

texts.en: K. Bimalohat is 53 years old, is married, and has three children. Already for five years she has been selling bedclothes and towels. She tries to choose various goods of good quality and attractive prices which allows her to keep her clientele. The business brings in a stable income and allows her to improve the living conditions for her family. Today, Bimalohat requests 1,500 USD to purchase more bedclothes and towels in order to increase the range of her goods. She would like to thank everybody for supporting her. The progress of Bimalohat’s business is in your hands. Your support will really help her. loans.use: To purchase bedclothes and towels to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
N. Joyce is a creative businesswoman, fifty-two years old who has two children. She deals in agricultural produce, especially tomatoes and has been doing this business for six years.

Joyce is utilizing the loan to add capital to her business for purchasing agricultural produce such as tomatoes. She collects tomatoes from the village and supplies to the markets in the town. She has obtained a plot of land on her own and built a house on it with her business profits.

Joyce’s aim is to expand the business to a large extent and to built some rental houses for extra daily income.

loans.use: To add capital to her business and purchase produce such as tomatoes

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Problems and money shortages never defeated Rano, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. Rano is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 40 years old, widow and has a child. For more than 7 years, she has operated a store where she sells kid’s clothing. Her store is well known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Rano hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her dearest child. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. With this purpose Rano requests $2500 USD. She promises to repay the loan in time and thanks everyone supporting her.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new clothing in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Mamyata

texts.en:
Mamyata J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to increase her stock.  Mamyata is 43-years-old and is married to a policeman. She has six children, all of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

texts.en:
Agnes F. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery.  Agnes is 45-years-old and is married to a peasant. She has seven children, all of whom go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Mable

texts.en: Mable N., 36, owns a bar which she has operated for three years.  She has six children, all of whom are going to school. Her husband, a photographer, helps her in the business most of the time. She is using the loan to purchase drinks such as sodas, Red Bull, Smirnoff, and beers to expand the business. She also has a saloon behind the bar. Her aim is to educate her children and, God willing, set up a new business.

loans.use: To purchase additional drinks to expand the business.

loans.name: Aurelie

texts.en:
Aurelie M. is 47 years old, and she is married with six children aged between 23 and 12. She lives in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, where she has owned a small clothes shop since 2006. She employs one person in her business and opens her business every day from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

Aurelie is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to earn more profit so that she will be able to pay school fees for her children, expand her business, and save money for the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

texts.en: Wasuk T. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking materials. Wasuk is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en: K. Herbert is an energetic thirty-six year old businessman. He has a retail shop in his local area, which his wife helps him run. He also has a car for hire. He is using his loan to bring more goods into his shop, such as sugar, soap, salt, maize flour, etc. His future plan is to purchase another car for transporting or hiring out for more income.  He has six family members, and would like to help his children get a university education.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for his shop

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy G. is a 54-year-old woman from Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband, Benjamin, 55, works for a construction firm. Two of their ten children are in school. The eldest is already working. Daisy has a general store in front of their house. In the afternoon, she sets up a table in front of her store to sell balut and barbecue (a balot or balut is a fertilized duck (or chicken) egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and eaten in the shell). She makes P1,500 everyday doing this. She has been enjoying her business for the last ten years. Daisy joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 upon the invitation of a friend. She is now on her 8th loan. She needs additional capital for the expansion of her business so she applied for a new loan of P12,000. Daisy hopes to own a grocery store someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

texts.en:
K. Pastoli is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 45 years old and married with 5 children, with the eldest at the university.

He is grateful for what the loans are doing for him, his business and family. He hopes to continue using them. He has had a shoe selling business in Kyaliwajjala, Namugongo for 25 years. His secret to business success is having enough stock for his customers at the right time.

Pastoli has a dream of educating his children and taking care of them in all aspects of life for a better future. He needs a loan to be able to buy more shoes for sale for increased stock.

Nyikang C. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to build a charcoal store.

Nyikang is 48 years old with a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Nakato

texts.en:
N. Nakato has a retail shop which she has been running for two years. She studied up to Ordinary level but due to some problems she was unable to continue studying.

She became an entrepreneur and started her business. She has six children. She is using the loan to purchase more things such as soap, drinks, sugar, rice, etc. for the shop. She is working hard to obtain a plot of land in their local area to build houses for renting.

loans.use: To purchase more retail things such as soap, drinks, sugar, rice, etc in the shop.

loans.name: Mandira

texts.en:
Mandira A. is currently in the business of selling milk tea and bread at the resturant and is requesting a loan to purchase more milk for tea in her resturant. 

 Mandira is 24 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more milk for tea in her resturant

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: N. Jane is operating the clothes business in Kampala town. She is a business woman of twenty-eight years old. She is living with the husband and they have five children. She has been doing the business for over four years. Her husband has a furniture workshop. She is using the loan to put more clothes for the season especially she is targeting Christmas season because people tend to buy more and more clothe in this season. She wishes to renovate her house and enlarge on her business.

loans.use: To put more clothes for the season especially she is targeting Christmas season

loans.name: Eva's Group

texts.en:
N. Eva is a hardworking and determined lady and the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a mother of 4 children and in full charge of their well-being, having divorced her husband.

She is grateful that so far she has been able to educate her children -- with 1 at the university while the rest are in secondary school -- all because of loans. The loans help her restock her shop with more products that in turn bring in more income, hence savings.

She has also been able to build a house for her children, having lost the one they had to her co-wife. She yearns for more achievements.

Her retail shop is located in Kyetume and she needs a loan to restock it further for expansion.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more products.

texts.en:
Marietta C. lives in Tala, Caloocan City. She is 40 years old. Her husband Benjamin works as an office employee. They have three children.

Six years ago, Marietta established her small general store in the ground floor of their house. Joining the Center for Community CCT in 2007 brought her many blessings. The loans provided by the cooperative helped her in the progress of her business.

From her profits, and with the help of some loans from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, she was able to build an extension to her house which she rents out to boarders and transients. She was also able to send her children to school. She now earns close to P17,000.00 a month from the combined operations of the store and apartment.

Marietta is now on her 6th loan cycle with the cooperative. She is asking for a new loan in the amount of P10,000.00 to buy more stocks for her general store. Portion of the funds will go to the minor repairs in the apartment.

She dreams of owning a large grocery store. She also hopes to expand her apartment soon.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

N. Mariam is a hardworking business lady, 29 years old. She has a hardware business, mainly selling cement. She has been in this business for four years. Her husband is also in business, and they have two children. She is using this loan to bring in more cement for the shop to fill her customers’ orders. Her main goal is to educate her children in good institutions.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Antoinette M. is a widow, 46 years old. She has one child, 20 years old.

Antoinette has been in the business of public secretariat for five years working eleven hours a day by employing two people.

Antoinette is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by purchasing more equipment and repairing some of the damaged ones.

Through accessing this new loan, Antoinette hopes to earn more profit than before and, through that profit, she plans to send her child to university.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more equipment and repairing others

texts.en: N. Passy is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 30 years old and married with 3 children with the eldest being 13 and in Primary seven. She is a strong business lady and a tailor for 4 years. At the moment, out of the clothes she makes, she is able to make 50,000/= as weekly profits and would like this to increase in future. She will be able to expand her business by including the sale of clothing materials and already made clothes so as to increase revenue by expanding her business. Passy also hopes to buy a plot of land where she will construct rental houses. She needs a loan to help buy more clothes for sewing as well as to complete the payment of her children’s school fees.

Susana G. is among the many people relocated from a shanty town in Manila City in the late '70s. Fifteen years ago, she ventured into a business selling charcoal for household fuel. Her business grew gradually until she was able to establish a general merchandise store selling grocery items and rice. Later she added commercial feed for livestock. She is now earning 30,000 PHP per month. Susana is a hardworking entrepreneur living along the rolling hills of Camarin in Caloocan City with her husband, Reynaldo, 42, a driver by profession.

In 2006, Susana got to know about the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative from a longtime member and became a member herself. She is now on her twelfth loan cycle and has applied for a new loan of 30,000 PHP to be used for the expansion of her businesses. Susana dreams of owning a taxicab for her husband soon.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Samuel's Group

texts.en: I. Samuel is a 49 year old man and married with 6 children aged 30 – 14 years with 4 still in school. He is a business man involved in the sale of coffee and goats from Nabuti village for 20 years now and this kind of exposure has won him more customers. He has his own suppliers that bring the goods from the villages to his store hence saving on the would be transport. He makes sure that he pays cash to those that supply to him and in this; he ensures that he does not run out of stock. Samuel has a dream of buying a lorry to be used to collect the goods from the farmers at their farms as well as rent it out for more earnings. He also hopes to start a poultry farm in the near future. At the moment, Samuel needs a loan to help buy more fresh and dry coffee for increased stock.

loans.use: Buying more coffee for increased stock.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: W. Sarah is a business woman of thirty-nine years old, married with two children studying.  She operates a bar business and it is over five years in her business. She is using the loan in purchasing bar items such as beers, waragi, sodas, water, etc to expand on her business. Her future dream is to buy a plot of land

loans.use: For purchasing bar items such as beers, waragi, sodas, water, etc to expand on her business.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
This is Julieta F., a 42-year-old jolly mother of three children living in Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband, Charlie, 36, is a driver. Julieta has been cooking and selling banana cue – a famous street snack made of caramelized bananas skewered on thin bamboo sticks – for three years now. Banana cue is a very popular, affordable and nutritious snack among students and workers. She earns close to 6,000 PHP a month. Her profits help meet her family’s daily needs.

Julieta joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just last year. She is about to finish repaying her previous loan with the cooperative. She has already applied for a new loan of 10,000 PHP for business expansion. She will buy ingredients for her banana cue like ripe bananas, brown sugar and cooking oil. She wants to sell her banana cue in other areas of the city by setting up another stall in the near future. It is also her dream to see her children finish their college education.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make banana cue

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: B. Jane is a business woman of thirty-seven years old. She has grocery selling ground nuts in Owino market in Kampala town. She has been in her business for three years. She deals with ground nuts as well, she sells even the grinned ground nuts because she has the ground nuts grinding machine. She is using the loan to purchase bags of ground nuts at least five and above bags of ground nuts expanding on her business. She has two children and her hope is to build some rental houses for more income earning.

loans.use: To purchase bags of ground nuts at least five and above bags of ground nuts expanding on her business.

texts.en:
Teresa D. C. sells movies in VCD and DVD formats as well as audio CDs in a small space in the market. She also sells RTW (ready-to-wear) dresses along with her CDs. Teresa is a 42-year-old woman living in Tala, Caloocan, City with her husband, Edwin (a businessman), and their four children. On a daily basis, her net income ranges from 200 PHP to 300 PHP. Teresa has been enjoying her business for nine years now and dreams of having a large boutique so she can employ the services of her friends.

Teresa has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2007. She is now on her fifth loan cycle and expects to receive her newest loan of 10,000 PHP so she can buy new movie titles to sell.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: N. Irene is a hardworking salon business lady of twenty-eight years old, single lady with two children. She is a professional in dressing hair. She has been doing her business for three years. She is using the loan to buy some new machines and chemicals for the salon that of course for the excellent work to attract more and more customers. She wishes to construct the rental houses for more income generating

loans.use: To buy some new machines and chemicals for the salon

texts.en:
Vedaste N. was born in 1973, married and he has 3 children aged between 6 and 2.
 
Vedaste has a saloon since 2002 in which he employs 7 people working from 7:00 A.M to 9h30’ P.M. Vedaste is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for the purpose of expanding his saloon in its size and purchasing many equipments to use in his saloon. With that expansion, Vedaste hopes to employe  more than 7 people and get more profit than before.

By using this new loan, Vedaste hopes to change his life by saving for the future and getting more food for his family.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. manages a photocopying service center. She also sells school and office supplies plus electronic load credits for mobile phones. Teresita is a 52-year-old woman living in Soldiers Hills, Caloocan City. Her husband, Fernando, 51, is a technician. They have two adult children. Teresita has been in her business for ten years. She earns 16,000 PHP net income per month (especially on school days).

Teresita became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. Her place of business is located near a marketplace and transport terminal, but it’s too small. She has been planning to expand it. She applied for a loan of 24,000 PHP to undertake repairs to her shop and to restock school and office supplies to sell.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Expansion of an office supplies store and photocopying center

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
This is Elsa B., a young businesswoman who lives among the poor communities in Tala, Caloocan City. She is 27 years old. Her husband, Rengel, also 27, works at a construction firm. One of their two children attends preschool.

Elsa started cooking and selling food items and breakfast goodies to her neighbors two years ago, the same year she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. Every morning, after cooking her food items, she sets up a small table for her wares in front of a friend’s store along an alley where a lot of people pass by.  She is earning 4,000 Philippine pesos (about $85) a month. She is happy that she can help her husband augment their basic daily needs.

She is now in need of a loan in the amount of P8,000 to buy food ingredients. Some of the loan will go to her child’s education. Elsa dreams of having her own permanent place of business, more like a restaurant.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy food ingredients for her business

texts.en:
Jacqueline N. is 24 years old, married and she has one kid of 4 months age
Jacqueline has an experience of 1 year in shopping  by starting from 6h30’ A.M to 19h00’.

Jacqueline is now requesting her first loan in Vision Finance Company s.a  for the purpose of expanding her shop through buying many goods. With that expansion, Jacqueline hopes to get more profit than before then with that profit, she will be able to buy a house and save for the future.

Through accessing this loan, Jacqueline hopes to see her life changing in a positive way.

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: N. Hadijah is a business woman of forty-one years old. She deals with buying old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bar and selling them to factory for recycling. She has been doing this business for over six years. She has two children. She is using the loan to add more capital in the business as in purchasing old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bars. She wants to expand the business to a large scale.

loans.use: To add more capital in the business as in purchasing old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bars and sell to factory for recycling.

loans.name: Night

texts.en: N. Night has a restaurant that supplies food to people in the market area. She has been doing this business for three years. N. has three children who have also been struggling for a living since they have grown up. She is asking for a loan in order to invest more in her business by purchasing a variety of foods to meet the different tastes of her customers. Her future plan is to set up a good restaurant in town and start outside catering.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of foods.

loans.name: Eliah's Group

texts.en: W. Eliah is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 45 years old and married with 6 children and all still in school as he takes care of other orphans. She is a business man involved in the stone quarrying business in Katikolo for 4 years and able to make 25,000/= as profits a week. Eliah says that the main challenge with his business is the climate change, mostly the rainy season that deters him to work best. He has a plan of getting more capital to be able to buy another piece of land from where he can quarry more stones for sell. He hopes that with this expansion, he will be able to more than double his profits.

loans.use: Buying a land to be used for stone quarrying.

texts.en:
Jean claude H. is 25 years old, single and he owns a photocopy machine since 2008.

He employs 3 people in his services; Jean claude  starts working from 7h30’ A.M to 21:00 P.M
He is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for the purpose of expanding his business through buying as new photocopy machine as possible in order to make a high profit.

By receiving this loan, Jean claude expects to save for his future and creating more jobs than before.

Monica W. is a 31 year-old mother married to Peter Mungai with two children, age 9 and 12 years, respectively, in school. Monica has been operating a retail business for the last four years.

She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend who is also a KADET client. This will be Monica’s first loan from KADET and she has had no previous loans from any micro finance institution. Monica will use this loan to restock her shop.

Monica's future dream and aspiration is to expand her small shop into a supermarket and to maximize profits and her family sustainability.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.name: Chalmita Group

texts.es:
ESPERANZA M. V.
(GRUPO CHALMITA)


Esperanza o como comúnmente la conocen en su comunidad “Pera” habita en un pequeño poblado llamado El Lindero, el mas alejado  de la Comunidad Indígena de Crescencio Morales en el Municipio de Zitacuaro, Michoacán, es una joven alegre de 19 años que desea invertir en una tienda de abarrotes, aprovechando la buena ubicación de su hogar pues se encuentra junto a la primaria del pueblo. 

Su plan es surtir de abarrotes un local y tener un micronegocio de donde obtener recursos para mantener a su pequeñita de 2 años de edad, ya que “Pera” desde muy Jovencita fue madre soltera y ahora su mayor anhelo es trabajar mucho para darle a su niña todo lo que necesita. 

Pera se unió al grupo Chalmita  para solicitar el financiamiento, ella es una de las dos personas que invertirán en comercio, pues la mayor parte de las integrantes de este grupo invertirán en ganado ovino para crianza.

Esperanza al igual que las integrantes de su grupo, es una persona trabajadora acostumbrada a realizar labores en el campo, a caminar largas distancias y a levantarse a primera hora del día para realizar sus labores agrícolas, comerciales o pecuarias. 

Nota: la señora Juevntina Mondragón quizo aparece en la foto con sus familires, pero ella no pertenece al grupo.
texts.en:
Esperanza Mondragón V. Chalmita Group Esperanza, or “Pera”, as she is known in the community, lives in a small village called El Lindero. It is in the furthest outskirts of the Indígena de Crescencio Morales community in the Zitacuaro municipality of Michoacán. She is a happy 19 year old young woman who wishes to invest in a grocery store and take advantage of her house’s location. It is next to the town’s elementary school. Her plan is to stock a location with groceries and have a mini-business where she can get income to support her small two year old. Pera became a single mother at a very young age. Now her biggest goal is to work to give her daughter everything that she needs. Esperanza, like the other members of the group, is a hard-working person. She is accustomed to working in the field, walking long distances, and getting up at daybreak to do her work such as farming, commercial activities, or taking care of animals. Note: Juevntina Mondragón wanted to be in the photo with her relatives, but she does not belong to the group.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising sheep and a grocery store

texts.en:
Collins N. is a 25-year-old man who is married to Elizabeth Wairimu and together they have a two-year-old son. 

Collins has been selling second hand clothes for the last five years.

With no previous borrowing from any micro finance institution, he got to know about KADET through various marketing and promotional activities done by KADET staff in Naivasha town. 

This will be Collins’ second loan from KADET and he plans to use this loan to add more stock.

His future dream and aspiration is to open a boutique with different kinds of stock.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

Esther K. is 33 years, married with 4 children aged between 7 and 1.

Esther has a shop for 10 years, she employs 1 people starting from 7h00 A.M to 7h00 P.M. Esther is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for expanding her business through purchasing rice, sugar and palm oil and other goods for sale.

Through accessing this loan, Esther hopes to see the life of her family changing positively.

Callixte H. is 30 years old, married with 3 children aged between 5 and 1.

Callixte has an experience of 8 years in shopping by working from 7h00 A.M to 8h00 P.M. After realizing that his investment is too low to get enough profit, Callixte is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a  for the purpose of increasing the profit.

With this profit, Callixte hopes to buy a house and pay school fees for his children.

Veronique U. is 38 years, widow with one child of 16 years old.

Veronique has been doing the business of restaurant for the past 4 years and as of right now, she employs 4 people starting from 6 h00A.M to 8h00 P.M. After realizing that Veronique is in lack of equipments to use in her restaurant so that she may offer a qualitative service, she is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a  in order to expand her business.

With that expansion, Veronique hopes to get more profit than before and through that profit, she will be able to buy her own house and save for her child.

texts.es:
En el departamento de Masaya, la señora Lucía del Carmen S. dedica sus esfuerzos a su actividad de pulpería donde a diario ofrece los productos para lograr mejorar su condición económica.

Actualmente, la señora Lucía solicitó un crédito para la compra de los productos de pulpería y por este motivo es que ella espera que su crédito sea otorgado y de esta manera proceder a la compra de los productos tales como comestibles y bebidas para la pulpería.

El joven Alonso Antonio M. es muy esforzado ya que dedica su tiempo a atender su negocio el cual consiste en un pequeño cafetín donde vende café, jugos, gaseosas y también productos comestibles estando ubicado en una calle céntrica en el departamento de Masaya donde es visitado por los clientes.

Hoy en día, Alonso solicitó un crédito para la compra de las bebidas y los comestibles para comercializarlos y de esta manera continuar desarrollando su negocio que tanto requiere de inversión.
texts.en:
The young man Alonso Antonio M. is very dedicated since he devotes his time to attending to his business, which consists of a small café where he sells coffee, juices, soft drinks, and also food. The café is located in a downtown street where he is visited by his customers in the department of Masaya. Right now, Alonso is applying for a loan for the purchase of drinks and foods in order to sell them in his café and in this way continue developing his business, which requires the investment so much

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en:
Mediatrice M. is 43 years old, is married, and she has six children aged between 24 and 14.

Mediatrice has owned a small shop since 2006 and she employs one person. She opens her shop from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. It is after realizing that her shop is too small to earn enough profit that Mediatrice is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her shop through purchasing more goods.

Through accessing this loan, Mediatrice hopes to earn enough profit and, with that profit, she will be able to help her husband buy a house and get more food for the family.

loans.use: To expand her shop by purchasing more merchandise

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
La microempresaria Maria Luisa M. Jarquín tiene 41 años de edad, es madre soltera tiene 5 hijos y desde hace 4 años se dedica a viajar a las comunidades para vender ropas, principalmente pantalones de hombres y mujeres, blusas, faldas, shorts entre otras prendas de vestir.

Por su situación de madre soltera le ha tocado mantener a todos sus hijos a ella sola y por tal razón es que se dedica a esta actividad la cual le deja un poco ganancia, sin embargo por la situación del desempleo no tiene muchas alternativas. Hay que señalar que parte del producto que lleva lo obtiene al crédito y solamente le  dan de plazo un mes para regresar la plata y en ocasiones ella da crédito a sus clientes sin contar con el apoyo económico.

Por lo planteado esta solicitando se le financie para comprar los siguientes productos:

10 unidades de Pantalones de hombre a US 12 compra cada unidad, 10 unidades de pantalón de mujer estilo pescador a US 10 cada unidad, 12 unidades de  blusas a US 8 cada unidad, 12 unidades de faldas a US 8 cada unidad y 11 unidades de short de varón a US 8 cada unidad.
texts.en:
Maria Luisa M. Jarquín is a 41 year old entrepreneur. She is a single mother with five children. For four years she has traveled to other communities to sell clothes. She primarily sells men’s and women’s pants, blouses, skirts, and shorts among other articles of clothing. Being a single mother, it falls to her alone to support all of her children. That is why she works selling clothes, which gives her a little income. Nevertheless, with the unemployment situation she has few alternatives. She gets part of the products she sells with credit. They only give her one month to repay the money. She is left without operating funds because she sometimes extends credit to her strapped customers She is asking for a loan to buy the following products: 10 pairs of men’s pants @ $12 per pair, 10 pairs of women’s capri pants @ $10 per pair, 12 blouses @ $8 per blouse, 12 skirts @ $8 per skirt, and 11 pairs of men’s shorts at $8 per pair.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy men's pants, capri pants, blouses, skirts, and men's shorts

texts.en: Agnes is 57 years old. She is married and has given birth to seven children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Agnes is a trader. She trades in pastries. She supplies retailers and snack bar operators in her community. She sells food (rice and stew) as well. Agnes buys her goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for over six years and wants a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

texts.es:
Lucía del Carmen es una madre de familia que a pesar de ser soltera ha logrado llevar el sustento a sus pequeños en su localidad. Ella se desempeña como empleada domestica en un restaurante del departamento de Masaya y está invirtiendo para remodelar su vivienda ya que no presta las condiciones necesarias para vivir por lo que ha estado muy dañada y para ello solicita el crédito.

Al adquirir el crédito lo invertirá directamente en la compra de los materiales de construcción para remodelar su vivienda y de esta manera contribuirá al desarrollo y mejora del bienestar de su familia.

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mamadou Samaké est un polygame de 34 ans qui vit avec ses épouses et ses deux enfants  dans une famille traditionnelle à Ouéléssébougou, une des sous- préfecture relevant  de Koulikoro,  deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Suite aux difficultés de la vie, il quitta l’école très tôt pour faire le manœuvre à l’usine d’égrainage coton de la Compagnie Malienne de Développement Textile du Mali (CMDT) durant  trois ans. C’est avec ces épargnes qu’il entama la vente en détail de carburants  jusqu’à ce qu’aujourd’hui il  est parvenu à ouvrir une station service de  vente de carburants et  de lubrifiants. Il est très apprécié et sollicité à Ouéléssébougou pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il fait recours au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt individuel.  
Il compte avoir avec ce prêt  600  litres de lubrifiants et s’approvisionne à Bamako une fois par mois auprès des grossistes. Il effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et quelques rare fois à crédit, à une clientèle composée généralement de propriétaires de motos  et de véhicules.
Il estime pouvoir réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 65.000 FCFA qui servira à   payer les échéances du prêt et être réinvestir dans son entreprise.

texts.en: Dorothy is thirty years old. She is married and has give birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Dorothy is a trader. She trades in fried fish. She fries herself and supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. She buys fresh fish and other working materials from nearby towns. Dorothy has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy cartons of fish and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is 45 years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She is a trader. She trades in fish and vegetables. Comfort sells on a table top in the market square and supplies retailers and food vendors in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Comfort has been in business for 10 years and wants a loan to buy cartons of fish and vegetables in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fish and vegetables in bulk

texts.en: Ophelia is thirty years old. She is married and has give birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She is a trader. She trades in food stuffs such as plantain. She sells at the local market and supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Ophelia has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy plantain in bulk to expand her business.

Mary is fifty – six years old. She is divorced and has give birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Mary is a trader. She trades in provision and other food items. She sells in a store by the road side in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Mary has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

texts.fr:
